div.l: But be my thrift yit shal I blere her yhe
For all the sleiȝte in her Philosophie
The more queint cercles þᵗat they make
The more will I stele whan I take
In stede of floure yit wol I yiue hem bren̄
The grettest clerkes ben nouȝt the wisest men
As whilom to the wolf thus spak the mare
Of all hir art counte I nouȝt a tare
Out of the dore he goth ful preuily
Whan that he saugh his tyme softly
He loketh vp and doun̄ til he hath founde
Theȝ clerke hors there it stood I bounde
Behinde the mylle vnder a Leuesill
And to the hors he goth him faire ⁊and well
He putteth of the bridell faire ⁊and riȝt anon̄
And whan̄ the hors was lose he gan to gon̄
Toward the fen ther wilde mares renne
And forth with we he throuȝ thik ⁊and thenne
The Miller goth agein no thing he saide
And thus with the clerkes he plaide
Til that the corn was wel ⁊and faire I grounde
And whan the mele is sacked ⁊and I bounde
This Iohn goth out ⁊and fynt his hors awey
And gan to crie harrow and welawey
Oure hors is lost Aleyn for goddes bones
Steppe on thi foot com on man al atones
Alas oure wardein hath his palfrey lorn̄
This Aleyn al forgat mele ⁊and corne
All was out of his mynde his husbondrie
What whilke way is he gon he gan to crie
The wif com leping in at a renne
She said Allas your hors goth to the fenne
With wilde mares as faste as he may go
Vnthank on his hand that band him so
And he that better shuld a knyt the reyne
Allas quod Iohn Aleyn for cristes peyne
Ley doun thi swerd and I will myn also
I is full swifte god wot as is a Roo
Be goddes herte he shal nat scape vs bathe
Whi ne had thou put the capill in the lathe
Il haill Aleyn be god thou is a fonne
Theȝ seli clerkies haue full faste I ronne
Toward the fenne bothe Aleyn ⁊and eke Iohn
And whan the Millere sigh that they were gon̄
He half a busshel of flour hath I take
And bad his wif go knede it in a cake
He seid I trowe the clerkes were aferde
Yet can̄ a Millere make a Clerkes berd
For al his art yit lat him go his weye
Lo where he goth ya lat the childre pleye
They gete him nat so liȝtly be my crowne
These seli clerkes renne vp and doun̄
With kepe kepe stond stond iossa war arrere
Ga whistell thou and I shal kepe him hiere
But shortly til it was verri niȝt
They coude nat thouȝ they dede al her miȝt
Her capill cacche he ran awey so faste
Til in a dich they cauȝt him ate laste
Wery and wete as beste is in the reyn
Comth seli Iohn ⁊and with him comth Aleyn̄
Allas quod Iohn that I was born̄
Now ar we driuen to brething ⁊and to scorn̄
Oure corn̄ is stole men wol vs fooles calle
Bothe the wardein and oure felawes alle
And nameli the Mallere welaway
Thus pleineth Iohn as he goth by the way
Toward the mille and bayard on his hond
The Millere sitting by the fyre he fond
For it was niȝt and forther they miȝt nat
But for loue of god they him besouȝt
Of herberugh and ese for his peny
The Millere said agein if the be any
Such as it is yit shul ye haue your part
Myn hous istreite but ye han lerned art
Ye can be argumentez make a place
A myle brod of xx foot of space
Lat se now wif this place may suffice
Or make it rom with speche as is your guise
Now Symond seid this Iohn be seint Cutberd
Ay is thou mery and faire is it ansuerd
I haue herd sey men take of twa thinges

Such as he fynt orellis take swilk as he bringes It appears that "bringes" was marked for correction with an "X" and perhaps an "h" added; it then appears that a "?" was added above the "X" and that finally the "X," the "h," and the "?" were all scraped, although unevenly.
But specialli I pray the oost diere
Gete vs som mete ⁊and drink ⁊and make vs chere
And we woll pay truly at the fulle
With empti hand men may non haukes tolle
